trans-unit.source: Use Logic App features
trans-unit.target: Use Logic App features

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the advanced features of logic apps.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the advanced features of logic apps.

trans-unit.source: In the <linkText>previous topic[create a new logic app]</linkText><title></title>, you created your first logic app.
trans-unit.target: In the <linkText>previous topic[create a new logic app]</linkText><title></title>, you created your first logic app.

trans-unit.source: Now we will show you how to build a more complete process using App Services Logic Apps.
trans-unit.target: Now we will show you how to build a more complete process using App Services Logic Apps.

trans-unit.source: This topic introduces the following new Logic Apps concepts:
trans-unit.target: This topic introduces the following new Logic Apps concepts:

trans-unit.source: Conditional logic, which executes an action only when a certain condition is met.
trans-unit.target: Conditional logic, which executes an action only when a certain condition is met.

trans-unit.source: Repeating actions.
trans-unit.target: Repeating actions.

trans-unit.source: Code view to edit an existing logic app.
trans-unit.target: Code view to edit an existing logic app.

trans-unit.source: Options for starting a workflow.
trans-unit.target: Options for starting a workflow.

trans-unit.source: Before you complete this topic, you should complete the steps in [Create a new logic app].
trans-unit.target: Before you complete this topic, you should complete the steps in [Create a new logic app].

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure portal], browse to your logic app and click Triggers and Actions in the summary to edit the logic app definition.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure portal], browse to your logic app and click Triggers and Actions in the summary to edit the logic app definition.

trans-unit.source: You may find the follow documents useful:
trans-unit.target: You may find the follow documents useful:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Management and runtime REST APIs</linkText><title></title> - including how to invoke Logic apps directly
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Management and runtime REST APIs</linkText><title></title> - including how to invoke Logic apps directly

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Language reference</linkText><title></title> - a comprehensive list of all supported functions/expressions
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Language reference</linkText><title></title> - a comprehensive list of all supported functions/expressions

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Trigger and action types</linkText><title></title> - the different types of actions and the inputs they take
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Trigger and action types</linkText><title></title> - the different types of actions and the inputs they take

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Overview of App Service</linkText><title></title> - description of what components to choose when to build a solution
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Overview of App Service</linkText><title></title> - description of what components to choose when to build a solution

trans-unit.source: Although the original flow works, there are some areas that could be improved.
trans-unit.target: Although the original flow works, there are some areas that could be improved.

trans-unit.source: First, the action only sends you the top tweet returned.
trans-unit.target: First, the action only sends you the top tweet returned.

trans-unit.source: Logically, you would want to receive all of the tweets with the keyword.
trans-unit.target: Logically, you would want to receive all of the tweets with the keyword.

trans-unit.source: To repeat an action for a list of items, such as the returned tweets, you must use the repeat property.
trans-unit.target: To repeat an action for a list of items, such as the returned tweets, you must use the repeat property.

trans-unit.source: Repeat takes a list of items and executes the action for each item in that list.
trans-unit.target: Repeat takes a list of items and executes the action for each item in that list.

trans-unit.source: The following steps update the existing action to use repeats, which makes more sense for a list of tweets.
trans-unit.target: The following steps update the existing action to use repeats, which makes more sense for a list of tweets.

trans-unit.source: Return to the workflow you created and click the Definition link in the Essentials.
trans-unit.target: Return to the workflow you created and click the Definition link in the Essentials.

trans-unit.source: To edit the Dropbox connector action, click the pencil icon.
trans-unit.target: To edit the Dropbox connector action, click the pencil icon.

trans-unit.source: Click on the gear icon, and select Repeat over a list.
trans-unit.target: Click on the gear icon, and select Repeat over a list.

trans-unit.source: Next to the Repeat box click the ... and select Body.
trans-unit.target: Next to the Repeat box click the ... and select Body.

trans-unit.source: This will input:
trans-unit.target: This will input:

trans-unit.source: Into the text box.
trans-unit.target: Into the text box.

trans-unit.source: This function outputs a list of tweets.
trans-unit.target: This function outputs a list of tweets.

trans-unit.source: Select all of the text in the Content text box and delete it.
trans-unit.target: Select all of the text in the Content text box and delete it.

trans-unit.source: Then, click the ... and select Tweet Text.
trans-unit.target: Then, click the ... and select Tweet Text.

trans-unit.source: This will insert the repeatItem() function, which returns each element in the list.
trans-unit.target: This will insert the repeatItem() function, which returns each element in the list.

trans-unit.source: Finally, note that the outputs of repeating actions are special.
trans-unit.target: Finally, note that the outputs of repeating actions are special.

trans-unit.source: If you wanted to reference the results of the Dropbox operation, for example, you could not do the normal @actions('dropboxconnector').outputs.body, you would instead do: @actions('dropboxconnector').outputs.repeatItems.
trans-unit.target: If you wanted to reference the results of the Dropbox operation, for example, you could not do the normal @actions('dropboxconnector').outputs.body, you would instead do: @actions('dropboxconnector').outputs.repeatItems.

trans-unit.source: This returns a list of all of the times that the operation ran, along with the outputs of each.
trans-unit.target: This returns a list of all of the times that the operation ran, along with the outputs of each.

trans-unit.source: For example, @first(actions('dropboxconnector').outputs.repeatItems).outputs.body.FilePath will return the path of the first file uploaded.
trans-unit.target: For example, @first(actions('dropboxconnector').outputs.repeatItems).outputs.body.FilePath will return the path of the first file uploaded.

trans-unit.source: This logic app still results in a lot of files being uploaded to Dropbox.
trans-unit.target: This logic app still results in a lot of files being uploaded to Dropbox.

trans-unit.source: The following steps add additional logic to make sure that you only receive a file when the tweet has a certain number of retweets.
trans-unit.target: The following steps add additional logic to make sure that you only receive a file when the tweet has a certain number of retweets.

trans-unit.source: Click the gear icon at the top of the action and select Add a condition to be met.
trans-unit.target: Click the gear icon at the top of the action and select Add a condition to be met.

trans-unit.source: In the text box, type the following:
trans-unit.target: In the text box, type the following:

trans-unit.source: The function greater compares two values and only allows the action to be executed when the first value is greater than the second value.
trans-unit.target: The function greater compares two values and only allows the action to be executed when the first value is greater than the second value.

trans-unit.source: You access a given property as a dot (.)
trans-unit.target: You access a given property as a dot (.)

trans-unit.source: followed by the property name, such as .Retweet_Count above.
trans-unit.target: followed by the property name, such as .Retweet_Count above.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark to save the Dropbox action.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark to save the Dropbox action.

trans-unit.source: In addition to the designer, you can directly edit the code that defines a logic app, as follows.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the designer, you can directly edit the code that defines a logic app, as follows.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Code view button in the command bar.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Code view button in the command bar.

trans-unit.source: This opens a full editor that shows the definition you just edited.
trans-unit.target: This opens a full editor that shows the definition you just edited.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Code view</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Code view</linkText>

trans-unit.source: By using the text editor, you can copy and paste any number of actions within the same logic app or between logic apps.
trans-unit.target: By using the text editor, you can copy and paste any number of actions within the same logic app or between logic apps.

trans-unit.source: You can also easily add or remove entire sections from the definition, and you can also share definitions with others.
trans-unit.target: You can also easily add or remove entire sections from the definition, and you can also share definitions with others.

trans-unit.source: After you make your changes in code view, simply click Save.
trans-unit.target: After you make your changes in code view, simply click Save.

trans-unit.source: There are some capabilities of Logic Apps that can only be used in the code view.
trans-unit.target: There are some capabilities of Logic Apps that can only be used in the code view.

trans-unit.source: One example of these is parameters.
trans-unit.target: One example of these is parameters.

trans-unit.source: Parameters make it easy to re-use values throughout your logic app.
trans-unit.target: Parameters make it easy to re-use values throughout your logic app.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have an email address that you want use in several actions, you should define it as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have an email address that you want use in several actions, you should define it as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: The following updates your existing logic app to use parameters for the query term.
trans-unit.target: The following updates your existing logic app to use parameters for the query term.

trans-unit.source: In the code view, locate the parameters : {} object and insert the following topic object:
trans-unit.target: In the code view, locate the parameters : {} object and insert the following topic object:

trans-unit.source: Scroll to the twitterconnector action, locate the query value and replace it with #@{parameters('topic')}.
trans-unit.target: Scroll to the twitterconnector action, locate the query value and replace it with #@{parameters('topic')}.

trans-unit.source: You could also use the concat function to join together two or more strings, for example: @concat('#',parameters('topic')) is identical to the above.
trans-unit.target: You could also use the concat function to join together two or more strings, for example: @concat('#',parameters('topic')) is identical to the above.

trans-unit.source: Finally, go to the dropboxconnector action and add the topic parameter, as follows:
trans-unit.target: Finally, go to the dropboxconnector action and add the topic parameter, as follows:

trans-unit.source: Parameters are a good way to pull out values that you are likely to change a lot. They are especially useful when you need to override parameters in different environments. For more information on how to override parameters based on environment, see our <linkText>REST API documentation</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Parameters are a good way to pull out values that you are likely to change a lot. They are especially useful when you need to override parameters in different environments. For more information on how to override parameters based on environment, see our <linkText>REST API documentation</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Now, when you click Save, every hour you will get any new tweets that have more than 5 retweets delivered to a folder called tweets in your Dropbox.
trans-unit.target: Now, when you click Save, every hour you will get any new tweets that have more than 5 retweets delivered to a folder called tweets in your Dropbox.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Logic App definitions, see <linkText>author Logic App definitions</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Logic App definitions, see <linkText>author Logic App definitions</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: There are several different options for starting the workflow defined in you logic app.
trans-unit.target: There are several different options for starting the workflow defined in you logic app.

trans-unit.source: A workflow can always be started on-demand in the [Azure portal].
trans-unit.target: A workflow can always be started on-demand in the [Azure portal].

trans-unit.source: A recurrence trigger run at an interval that you specify.
trans-unit.target: A recurrence trigger run at an interval that you specify.

trans-unit.source: When the trigger has conditional logic, the trigger determines whether or not the workflow needs to run.
trans-unit.target: When the trigger has conditional logic, the trigger determines whether or not the workflow needs to run.

trans-unit.source: A trigger indicates it should run by returning a 200 status code.
trans-unit.target: A trigger indicates it should run by returning a 200 status code.

trans-unit.source: When is does not need to run, it returns 202 status code.
trans-unit.target: When is does not need to run, it returns 202 status code.

trans-unit.source: Services can call a logic app endpoint to start a workflow.
trans-unit.target: Services can call a logic app endpoint to start a workflow.

trans-unit.source: You can find the endpoint to access by navigating to the Properties blade from the Settings command bar button in your logic app.
trans-unit.target: You can find the endpoint to access by navigating to the Properties blade from the Settings command bar button in your logic app.

trans-unit.source: You can use this callback to invoke a logic app from inside your custom application.
trans-unit.target: You can use this callback to invoke a logic app from inside your custom application.

trans-unit.source: You need to use Basic authentication.
trans-unit.target: You need to use Basic authentication.

trans-unit.source: The username of default is created for you, and the password is the Primary Access Key field on the Properties blade.
trans-unit.target: The username of default is created for you, and the password is the Primary Access Key field on the Properties blade.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: You can pass outputs to the workflow and reference them in the workflow.
trans-unit.target: You can pass outputs to the workflow and reference them in the workflow.

trans-unit.source: For example, with the above trigger, if you include @triggers().outputs.property you will get value.
trans-unit.target: For example, with the above trigger, if you include @triggers().outputs.property you will get value.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>the REST documentation</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>the REST documentation</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can define a logic app that does not have a trigger.
trans-unit.target: You can define a logic app that does not have a trigger.

trans-unit.source: In this case the workflow must be started on-demand.
trans-unit.target: In this case the workflow must be started on-demand.

trans-unit.source: This kind of logic app is best suited for a process that only needs to run intermittently.
trans-unit.target: This kind of logic app is best suited for a process that only needs to run intermittently.

trans-unit.source: To create a logic app without a trigger, check the Run this logic manually in the Start logic box in the designer.
trans-unit.target: To create a logic app without a trigger, check the Run this logic manually in the Start logic box in the designer.

trans-unit.source: To start logic app on-demand, click the Run now button on the command bar.
trans-unit.target: To start logic app on-demand, click the Run now button on the command bar.
